details.summary: We develop and maintain relations between the United Kingdom and South Africa. The High Commission also covers Lesotho and Swaziland.
details.description: We deal with a wide range of political, commercial, security and economic questions of interest to the UK and South Africa. The High Commission, and our consulate in Cape Town, provide consular assistance to British nationals in South Africa.
details.services:
Visas

For information on whether you require a visa for the United Kingdom and how to apply go to the UK Border Agency website

Births, deaths and marriages

Information on how you can register a birth or death which occurred overseas, and legal documents for couples marrying or entering into civil partnerships abroad.

Passports and emergency travel documents

How to renew or replace your British passport when visiting the UK and information on getting replacement travel documents if your passport is lost or stolen.

Travel advice

Information on staying safe and avoiding problems when living or traveling abroad, with links to our embassies, high commissions and other diplomatic posts across the world.

Legalisation Service

How to get official confirmation that your UK public documentation is genuine so it can be accepted by foreign authorities. The UK does not require any documents to be legalised for use within the UK.

details.access_and_opening_times:
Opening times

GMT

Monday to Thursday 6am to 3pm and Friday 6am to 10:30am

Local time

Monday to Thursday 8am to 5pm and Friday 8am to 12:30pm

Consular section

Monday to Thursday: 8am to 12pm

Visa section

Monday to Thursday 8am to 4pm and Friday 8am to 12:30pm

Regional Passport Processing Centre is closed for the public.

Disabled access

The British Government is keen to ensure that buildings and services are fully accessible to disabled members of the public. Wherever possible, we have made our buildings and services accessible. Sometimes however, this is not possible due to security or other restrictions. In Pretoria, the High Commission is located in protected premises at 255 Hill Street (between Schoeman and Pretorius street) with the main entry for visitors being accessed from Hill Street. Access is controlled by security staff and all visitors are required to be cleared by security before being allowed access into the High Commission building. To assist disabled visitors, we have set out below details of disabled access at this High Commission. We hope this information is helpful.

General physical access

  • Entrances: there is one easy access available into the main High Commission building and prior notification is desirable
  • Toilets: there are toilet facilities which can accommodate wheelchairs
  • Floor coverings, doorways, and handles are of standard design
  • The entrance area is well lit
  • Emergency/evacuation: evacuation is on foot leading to most of the exit points. In case of an emergency, the High Commission staff will be able to assist

Access for visually-impaired visitors

  • Essential signage is clear and easy to read
  • Guide dogs are welcome
  • The Public Address system can be heard from all rooms within the building

Access for Deaf/hard of hearing visitors

  • Hearing loops are not currently available
  • There are no minicom or textphones
  • There are no sign language facilities
  • Hearing dogs are welcome

Contact us

Please let us know if you have any special requirements or would like to check what facilities we have for people with disabilities. Contact our main receptionist at the High Commission on 012 421 7500 who will try to find an alternative way of providing access for you.

details.summary: The British Consulate General is the professional and friendly face of modern Britain in Cape Town, South Africa’s parliamentary capital, and the three Cape Provinces.
details.description: We aim to promote British political, commercial, scientific and security interests in our region, working in partnership with the rest of the South Africa network of posts. We also provide consular assistance to British nationals who live in or visit this part of South Africa. We do not issue passports or visas.

details.summary: UK Trade & Investment (UKTI) helps UK-based companies succeed in the global economy. We also help overseas companies bring their high-quality investment to the UK’s dynamic economy.
details.description:
UKTI offers expertise and contacts through its extensive network of specialists in the UK, and in British embassies and other diplomatic offices around the world. We provide companies with the tools they require to be competitive on the world stage.

UKTI has offices in three key centres in South Africa. The main office is in Johannesburg with support offices in Cape Town and Durban.

Responsibilities

UKTI in South Africa helps companies in Britain increase their competitiveness through overseas trade in South Africa. We also offer professional, authoritative and personalised assistance to help companies in South Africa locate and expand in the UK.

Find out about how we are working with South Africa to achieve stronger economies.
details.services:
Start a business in the UK

UKTI offers dedicated, professional, personalised assistance to help you locate and expand your business in the UK, read about our investment services or contact us to find out more.

Export from the UK

UKTI can assist you on every step of the exporting journey in both the UK and overseas, read about our exporting services or contact us to find out more.

Events

UKTI and its partners stage events in the UK and abroad to help companies looking to export. You can browse scheduled events and register for alerts.

Business opportunities

UKTI is always looking to provide an international network of opportunities for UK Companies looking to export. You can search these opportunities and register for alerts.

UKTI team

To find out more about any of the services offered by UKTI you can contact a member of the UKTI South Africa team.

details.summary: We work in South Africa to encourage growth, job creation and the rights of women and children, and to improve health services and the public sector.
details.description:
South Africa has the largest economy in sub-Saharan Africa and is the only African member of the G20. Yet it continues to face challenges – with nearly 13 million people surviving on less than £1 per day, high youth unemployment and high rates of HIV.

DFID Southern Africa (DFID-SA) manages a £19m bilateral programme with South Africa.

Our top priorities are:

  • creating growth and jobs
  • helping South Africa move towards a lower carbon economy
  • improving health services, particularly for women and children
  • addressing physical and sexual violence against women and children
  • increasing public sector performance management and accountability
